text: was an old province in the area of Iwate and Akita prefectures on the island of Honshū.Nussbaum, Louis-Frédéric. (2005). "Rikuchū" in Japan Encyclopedia, p. 790. Along with Rikuzen Province and Mutsu Province, it was sometimes called . The history of the province started in 1868 and ended in 1872. ==History== In the Meiji period, the provinces of Japan were converted into prefectures. Maps of Japan and Rikuchū Province were reformed in the 1870s.Nussbaum, "Provinces and prefectures" at p. 780. ==Gallery== File:10Yen Stanp of Rikuchu Kaigan.JPG|10¥ Stamp showing rocks of Rikuchu at Jodogahama, c. 1955 File:5Yen Stanp of Rikuchu Kaigan.JPG|5¥ Stamp showing shoreline of Rikuchu at Kitayamasaki, c. 1955 File:Jyoudogahama.jpg|Jodogahama beach File:Kitayamasaki.jpg|Kitayamasaki cliffs ==Related pages== * Provinces of Japan * Prefectures of Japan * List of regions of Japan * List of islands of Japan * Sanriku ==References== ==Other websites == * Murdoch's map of provinces, 1903 Category:Former provinces of Japan Category:Akita Prefecture Category:Iwate Prefecture
title: Rikuchū Province
